<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 186, 170, 200]]<|/det|>
# PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 207, 279, 222]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Multiple Choice  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 248, 590, 291]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Multiple Choice Answer Sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 313, 386, 329]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 343, 235, 357]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 358, 595, 372]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 373, 890, 402]]<|/det|>
Write your name, Centre number and candidate number on the Answer Sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 890, 446]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions. For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 446, 890, 461]]<|/det|>
Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the separate Answer Sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 475, 555, 490]]<|/det|>
Read the instructions on the Answer Sheet very carefully.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 504, 764, 535]]<|/det|>
Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer. Any rough working should be done in this booklet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 96, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 816, 91]]<|/det|> A pendulum is set in motion and timed. The time measured for 20 complete swings is <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 598, 121]]<|/det|> What is the time for one complete swing of the pendulum? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 132, 695, 149]]<|/det|> **A** 0.67s **B** 0.75s **C** 1.5s **D** 3.0s <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 176, 96, 195]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 176, 900, 193]]<|/det|> Two stones of different weight fall at the same time from a table. Air resistance may be ignored. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 206, 346, 223]]<|/det|> What will happen and why? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 236, 885, 362]]<|/det|>
what will happenwhy
Aboth stones hit the floor at the same timeacceleration of free fall is constant
Bboth stones hit the floor at the same timethey fall at constant speed
Cthe heavier stone hits the floor firstacceleration increases with weight
Dthe heavier stone hits the floor firstspeed increases with weight
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 390, 96, 409]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 390, 664, 408]]<|/det|> The speed-time graph shown is for a bus travelling between stops. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 421, 607, 438]]<|/det|> Where on the graph is the acceleration of the bus greatest? <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 448, 803, 628]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 73, 751, 92]]<|/det|>
A large bag of feathers and a steel block balance each other on some scales.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[240, 98, 755, 240]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 252, 920, 285]]<|/det|>
What does this show about the masses and the weights of the bag of feathers and the steel block?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 295, 140, 314]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 295, 663, 314]]<|/det|>
It shows that the masses are equal and the weights are equal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 322, 140, 341]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 322, 727, 340]]<|/det|>
It shows that the masses are equal, but the weights might be different.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 348, 144, 367]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 348, 795, 365]]<|/det|>
It shows that the masses might be different and the weights might be different.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 374, 140, 392]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 374, 728, 392]]<|/det|>
It shows that the weights are equal, but the masses might be different.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 419, 96, 437]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 419, 568, 437]]<|/det|>
A parachutist inside an aeroplane has a mass of 70 kg.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 445, 586, 645]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 657, 600, 675]]<|/det|>
What is his mass after he has jumped from the aeroplane?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 686, 190, 704]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 686, 190, 704]]<|/det|>
0kg

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 713, 348, 730]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 713, 348, 730]]<|/det|>
between 0kg and 70kg

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 740, 200, 757]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 740, 200, 757]]<|/det|>
70kg

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 766, 304, 784]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 766, 304, 784]]<|/det|>
greater than 70kg

volume/cmÂ³mass/g
A2.016
B8.010

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 288, 96, 306]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 288, 920, 320]]<|/det|> The diagram shows sections of four objects of equal mass. The position of the centre of mass of each object has been marked with a cross. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 333, 386, 350]]<|/det|> Which object is the most stable? <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[180, 358, 814, 508]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 540, 96, 559]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 540, 824, 558]]<|/det|> A see-saw is made by resting a long plank of wood with its centre of mass on a barrel. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 571, 920, 603]]<|/det|> A boy sits on one side of the barrel and a girl sits on the other side so that the see-saw is balanced. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[285, 615, 707, 747]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 761, 380, 777]]<|/det|> Which statement **must** be true? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 789, 128, 807]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 789, 377, 806]]<|/det|> boy's weight = girl's weight <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 816, 346, 832]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 815, 346, 832]]<|/det|> distance \(x =\) distance \(y\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 842, 139, 859]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 842, 590, 858]]<|/det|> total downward force = total moment about the barrel <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 868, 139, 885]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 868, 572, 884]]<|/det|> resultant force and resultant moment are both zero

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 559, 90]]<|/det|>
A power station uses nuclear fission to obtain energy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 542, 120]]<|/det|>
In this process, nuclear energy is **first** changed into

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 132, 296, 148]]<|/det|>
A chemical energy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 158, 296, 174]]<|/det|>
B electrical energy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 184, 322, 200]]<|/det|>
C gravitational energy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 210, 337, 225]]<|/det|>
D thermal (heat) energy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 254, 107, 272]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 254, 549, 271]]<|/det|>
A person lifts boxes of equal weight on to a platform.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[245, 280, 750, 418]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 429, 606, 446]]<|/det|>
Which quantity will **not** affect the work done by the person?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 457, 510, 474]]<|/det|>
A the height of the platform above the ground

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 484, 370, 500]]<|/det|>
B the number of boxes lifted

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 510, 402, 526]]<|/det|>
C the time taken to lift the boxes

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 536, 348, 552]]<|/det|>
D the weight of the boxes

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 580, 107, 599]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 580, 920, 613]]<|/det|>
A skier walks from the bottom of a ski slope to the top and gains 10 000 J of gravitational potential energy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 625, 778, 642]]<|/det|>
She skis down the slope. At the bottom of the slope, her kinetic energy is 2000 J.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[351, 651, 643, 790]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 804, 920, 836]]<|/det|>
How much energy was converted into thermal energy and sound energy as the skier moved down the slope?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 847, 720, 864]]<|/det|>
A 2000J B 8000J C 10000J D 12000J

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 106, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>12</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 463, 90]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a mercury barometer.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[337, 100, 658, 280]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 292, 680, 310]]<|/det|>
Which distance is used to calculate the pressure of the atmosphere?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 320, 715, 338]]<|/det|>
A 25cm B 75cm C 80cm D 100cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 365, 106, 383]]<|/det|>
<label>13</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 365, 690, 383]]<|/det|>
A heavy table has six legs. The area of cross-section of each leg is \(X.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 396, 920, 429]]<|/det|>
The legs of the table make marks in a carpet. These marks become deeper with increased pressure.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 441, 704, 458]]<|/det|>
What would reduce the depth of the marks for a table of a fixed weight?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 470, 549, 488]]<|/det|>
A using three legs, each of an area smaller than \(X\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 496, 540, 513]]<|/det|>
B using four legs, each of an area the same as \(X\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 523, 532, 540]]<|/det|>
C using six legs, each of an area smaller than \(X\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 549, 549, 566]]<|/det|>
D using eight legs, each of an area the same as \(X\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>14</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 803, 90]]<|/det|>
Very small pollen grains are suspended in water. A bright light shines from the side.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 858, 135]]<|/det|>
Looking through a microscope, small specks of light are seen to be moving in a random manner.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[354, 144, 640, 450]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 464, 424, 481]]<|/det|>
What are the moving specks of light?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 492, 520, 510]]<|/det|>
**A** pollen grains being hit by other pollen grains

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 520, 504, 536]]<|/det|>
**B** pollen grains being hit by water molecules

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 546, 576, 562]]<|/det|>
**C** water molecules being hit by other water molecules

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 572, 504, 588]]<|/det|>
**D** water molecules being hit by pollen grains

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 616, 111, 634]]<|/det|>
<label>15</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 616, 690, 633]]<|/det|>
A swimmer feels cold after leaving warm water on a warm, windy day.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 645, 554, 662]]<|/det|>
Why does she feel cold even though the air is warm?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 674, 672, 690]]<|/det|>
**A** The less energetic water molecules on her skin escape quickly.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 700, 739, 716]]<|/det|>
**B** The more energetic water molecules on her skin do not escape quickly.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 726, 778, 743]]<|/det|>
**C** The water on her skin does not evaporate quickly enough to keep her warm.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 753, 650, 769]]<|/det|>
**D** The water on her skin evaporates quickly and cools her skin.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 796, 107, 814]]<|/det|>
<label>16</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 796, 856, 813]]<|/det|>
Which physical property is used to measure temperature in a liquid-in-glass thermometer?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 825, 400, 841]]<|/det|>
**A** the length of the thermometer

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 852, 404, 867]]<|/det|>
**B** the thickness of the glass bulb

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 878, 386, 893]]<|/det|>
**C** the volume of the glass bulb

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 904, 348, 919]]<|/det|>
**D** the volume of the liquid

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 715, 90]]<|/det|> The graph shows the temperature of a substance as it is heated steadily. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 537, 120]]<|/det|> In which part of the graph is the substance boiling? <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[138, 129, 855, 298]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 329, 107, 346]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 329, 920, 361]]<|/det|> A night storage heater contains a large block of material that is heated electrically during the night. During the day the block cools down, releasing thermal energy into the room. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 371, 580, 520]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 532, 920, 564]]<|/det|> Which thermal capacity and which night-time temperature increase will cause the most energy to be stored by the block? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 575, 562, 720]]<|/det|>
thermal capacity of blocknight-time temperature increase
Alargelarge
Blargesmall
Csmalllarge
Dsmallsmall
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 749, 107, 766]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 749, 890, 765]]<|/det|> After a sheep has its wool cut off, it is harder for it to stay warm when the air temperature falls. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 780, 524, 796]]<|/det|> How does the wool help the sheep to stay warm? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 808, 780, 824]]<|/det|> **A** Air can circulate between the wool fibres and heat up the skin by convection. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 834, 800, 850]]<|/det|> **B** Air trapped by the wool fibres reduces heat losses from the skin by convection. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 860, 871, 876]]<|/det|> **C** The wool fibres are curly so it takes longer for heat to be conducted away from the skin. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 886, 650, 902]]<|/det|> **D** The wool fibres conduct heat to the skin from the air outside.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>20</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 808, 91]]<|/det|>
A boy sits near a campfire. He pokes the fire with an iron bar. His hand becomes hot.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[322, 102, 668, 288]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 303, 703, 320]]<|/det|>
In which ways does thermal energy (heat) from the fire reach his hand?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 332, 415, 349]]<|/det|>
A conduction and convection only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 359, 397, 375]]<|/det|>
B conduction and radiation only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 384, 396, 400]]<|/det|>
C convection and radiation only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 410, 456, 426]]<|/det|>
D conduction, convection and radiation

amplitudefrequency

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 484, 107, 503]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 484, 541, 502]]<|/det|> Two bars of soft iron are placed near a bar magnet. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[252, 513, 744, 577]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 594, 804, 610]]<|/det|> Which row states and explains the behaviour of poles P and Q of the soft iron bars? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 622, 510, 750]]<|/det|>
P and Qreason
AattractP and Q are like poles
BattractP and Q are unlike poles
CrepelP and Q are like poles
DrepelP and Q are unlike poles

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>36</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 772, 91]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a wire in the magnetic field between two poles of a magnet.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[329, 100, 663, 236]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 252, 920, 286]]<|/det|>
The current in the wire repeatedly changes between a constant value in one direction and a constant value in the opposite direction. This is shown on the graph.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[245, 298, 750, 448]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 462, 370, 480]]<|/det|>
What is the effect on the wire?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 492, 141, 510]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 492, 825, 510]]<|/det|>
The force on the wire alternates between one direction and the opposite direction.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 520, 141, 537]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 520, 597, 537]]<|/det|>
The force on the wire is constant in size and direction.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 547, 141, 565]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 547, 546, 564]]<|/det|>
There is no force acting on the wire at any time.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 574, 141, 591]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 574, 643, 591]]<|/det|>
There is only a force on the wire when the current reverses.

<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 103, 337, 120]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 129, 141, 147]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 129, 339, 146]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 155, 327, 172]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 180, 349, 197]]<|/det|>
